title: Child Development: Imaginary Friend
headline: This free online psychology course explains how an imaginary friend can foster childhood development and creativity.
description: This psychology course lays out the role that imaginary friends can play in childhood development. Many parents feel concerned when they see their child engage in pretend play with invisible friends but we draw on established research conducted by psychologists over the years to address those fears. We also provide practical methods designed to enhance a child's creativity and boost their imagination as they develop during their early years.
courseDescription:
Have you seen your child engage in pretend play with an imaginary friend? Does it worry you? This child psychology course examines the role that imaginary friends can play in positively impacting childhood development and fostering creativity. We begin by defining the term ‘imaginary friend’ and identifying the usual age bracket during which a child may invent one. The course then provides a brief history and description of the common characteristics of these imaginary friends.

Having an imaginary friend can not only have a positive impact on your child’s development but is also linked to increased creativity during adulthood. We lay out the benefits of such connections and explain how parents can actually play an encouraging role in this aspect of their children’s lives through creative activities that help children develop their imagination and creativity. Rather than worrying about imaginary friends, parents can join in the fun and actually boost childhood development.

The course  goes over some useful techniques that can be used by parents and teachers alike to keep children busy and engaged while they make the most of their creativity. Imagination is one of the most important tools for children and parents or teachers must cultivate this quality from an early age. Sign up for this child psychology course to see how an imaginary friend or companion can be a positive sign for children as they develop and learn how to make the most of such ‘friendships’ to cultivate your child’s curiosity, creativity and sense of wonder.
